results.headline: A Horror Show
results.summary_short: The problem with “The Crazies?” Not crazy enough.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Crazies

results.headline: The Buddy-Police Recipe: Take Guns, Add Some Wisecracking, Stir
results.summary_short: From time to time, “Cop Out” offers glimpses of the giddy, goofy delight it might have been.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cop Out

results.headline: Manifesto From the Battle for the Barnes Collection
results.summary_short: “The Art of the Steal” is a hard-hitting documentary about a high-cultural brawl.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Art of the Steal

results.headline: Sex and Money and High Rollers (Memories Were Made of This)
results.summary_short: “The Good Guy” is fresh enough to provide the voyeuristic kick of glimpsing the frenzied lifestyle of aspiring masters of the universe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Good Guy

results.headline: Writer for Hire Is a Wanted Man
results.summary_short: With “The Ghost Writer,” Roman Polanski creates a wholly believable world rich in strange contradictions and ominous implications.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ghost Writer

results.headline: In an Ever-Changing New York, Falling in Love May Be the Only Constant
results.summary_short: The best thing about “The Last New Yorker” is its evocation of the relentless speed with which the city tears down and rebuilds itself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last New Yorker

results.headline: All at Sea, Surrounded by Red Herrings
results.summary_short: Martin Scorsese’s camera sense fills every scene with creepiness, but sustained suspense seems beyond him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shutter Island

results.headline: Documenting a Quarrelsome Marriage
results.summary_short: “Phyllis and Harold” is an impossibly self-involved portrait of a union far more commonplace than its offspring seem to believe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Phyllis and Harold

results.headline: The Many Shades of Family Dysfunction
results.summary_short: In “Happy Tears,” the writer and director Mitchell Lichtenstein struggles to find the humor in a host of horrors.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy Tears

results.headline: A Town Torn Asunder by Racial Killing in ’70
results.summary_short: Jeb Stuart’s “Blood Done Sign My Name” scrupulously examines a page from the recent history of the South.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Done Sign My Name

results.headline: Mysteries and Hopes Converge on a Shrine
results.summary_short: One of the pleasures of “Lourdes” is that it takes place in the space between the inexplicable (no explanation is possible) and the unexplained.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lourdes

results.headline: A Hero Begins His Quest, and Then the Trouble Starts
results.summary_short: “My Name Is Khan” is an effective exercise in Bollywood high emotionalism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Name is Khan

results.headline: The Mobsters of Palermo
results.summary_short: “To Die for Tano” is a bizarre musical comedy in which the actual severed swordfish heads are not the ugliest things on screen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tano da Morire

results.headline: It’s Hard to Be Refined as You Howl at the Moon
results.summary_short: The title character in “The Wolfman” suffers from a vexing identity crisis, and so does the movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wolfman

results.headline: Prime Minister, Primo Mogul
results.summary_short: “Videocracy” is a queasy-funny and unapologetically biased look at the televisual world that the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, has created.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Videocracy

results.headline: Home for the Holler Days: Visit Dad, Add Girlfriend
results.summary_short: There is a lot of hurting in the family melodrama “The Vicious Kind,” and a lot of healing too.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Vicious Kind

results.headline: A Whole Lotta Interconnected Love, and a Whole Lotta Movie Stars
results.summary_short: The dire romantic comedy “Valentine’s Day” is neither romantic nor remotely comedic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valentine's Day

results.headline: Another Teenage Woe: The Hounds of Hades
results.summary_short: In “Percy Jackson and the Olympians: The Lightning Thief,” virginal teenagers do battle with fire-belching monsters.
results.display_title: Percy Jackson and the Olympians: The Lightning Thief

results.headline: A Family in Need of a Generation Gap
results.summary_short: The filmmakers Michael Palmieri and Donal Mosher document a family’s woes in “October Country.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of October Country

results.headline: Swiss-American Adventurer
results.summary_short: How you feel about the odd little documentary “Barefoot to Timbuktu” will depend to an unusually large extent on how you feel about its subject.
